channel.title: MySQL and SQLYog help
channel.description:
okay i got the following procedure to work but the problem is that i want to see the actual command that you would write inorder for the procedure to work like if i wanted to import the data from the table into the fall073 database how would i do that NOT THROUGH the GUI but so i can see the command. im using SQLYog Community Edition -MySQL GUI v.8.14
Stored Procedure 5.
db = fall073 // table = // stored procedure name = CreateFullDatabase import the following tables into the database Norman: the language table from myworld with data the accounts table from fall073 without data
thanks

item.title: MySQL and SQLYog help
item.dc:creator: @darkilla darkilla

@darkilla wrote:

lmaoo okayy never mind i dont know how to explain it to you… n yeahh mopar thats exactly what i want haha would be MUCHH easier for me lol…

item.title: MySQL and SQLYog help
item.dc:creator: @inertia inertia
item.description:
@inertia wrote:

[quote=“Moparisthebest, post:6, topic:315854”][quote author=darkilla link=topic=412308.msg3040167#msg3040167 date=1259034810]
its part of a assignment… and yeah i kno the exact query you would type but i just wanted to know if there was an easier way instead of actually typing it the GUI would automatcially show me the command lol…
because when i manage columns and press alter it actually does show me the command but that only works when you are adding a primary key or new data.
is there a option to show the command lol ?
[/quote]

So you want a GUI program to show you the command it is using so you can copy it down and turn it in for your homework? Your teacher will probably catch on to that, and I don’t know anything about this tool, but phpmyadmin always shows you the command it runs.[/quote]

He doesn’t really have a clue what he’s on about, so neither will we.

Read full topic

item.title: MySQL and SQLYog help
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

[quote=“darkilla, post:5, topic:315854”]its part of a assignment… and yeah i kno the exact query you would type but i just wanted to know if there was an easier way instead of actually typing it the GUI would automatcially show me the command lol…
because when i manage columns and press alter it actually does show me the command but that only works when you are adding a primary key or new data.
is there a option to show the command lol ?[/quote]

So you want a GUI program to show you the command it is using so you can copy it down and turn it in for your homework? Your teacher will probably catch on to that, and I don’t know anything about this tool, but phpmyadmin always shows you the command it runs.

Read full topic

item.title: MySQL and SQLYog help
item.dc:creator: @inertia inertia
item.description:
@inertia wrote:

CREATE TABLE norman.language SELECT * FROM myworld.language

CREATE TABLE norman.accounts SELECT * FROM fall073.accounts WHERE false=true

What is the application of this? Is it a homework assignment or are you writing a batch job in PHP? I’m not actually sure if either of those queries will work, I’d personally cycle through all the data in the table and then connect to the other database and insert it in a loop. Obviously direct mysql queries would be a lot more efficient but that’d require a bit of googling on your behalf.

Read full topic

item.title: MySQL and SQLYog help
item.dc:creator: @darkilla darkilla
item.description:
@darkilla wrote:

lol umm i got the query correct using it through the GUI but i also wanted to know if there was a way to see the actual command you would type for that same query through MySQL command line way.

okay we have to take the language table from the database myworld and put into the norman database WITH DATA (which is currently empty)
also we have to take the accounts table from fall073 WITHOUT DATA and put it into norman

Read full topic

item.title: MySQL and SQLYog help
item.dc:creator: @inertia inertia
item.description:
@inertia wrote:

Let me get this straight…

DB: fall073
TABLE: myworld
TABLE: fall073
DB: norman
TABLE: language
TABLE: accounts

The table norman.accounts will have the same structure as fall073.fall073.
The table norman.language will have the same structure and data as fall073.myworld.
The two tables including and not including data on the database norman will be created using a query.

Yes?

Read full topic

item.title: MySQL and SQLYog help
item.dc:creator: @darkilla darkilla
item.description:
@darkilla wrote:

okay i got the following procedure to work but the problem is that i want to see the actual command that you would write inorder for the procedure to work
like if i wanted to import the data from the table into the fall073 database how would i do that NOT THROUGH the GUI but so i can see the command.
im using SQLYog Community Edition -MySQL GUI v.8.14

Stored Procedure 5.

db = fall073 // table = // stored procedure name = CreateFullDatabase
import the following tables into the database Norman:
the language table from myworld with data
the accounts table from fall073 without data

thanks
